title: When the beacon goes dark: How U.S. regression on social stances fuels global repression
content: From the 17th to 19th centuries, Western Europeans often condemned the Islamic East, not for conservatism, but for a liberty they found scandalous. The Ottoman Empire was arguably leading the world in sexual tolerance, having decriminalized homosexuality in 1858. That legacy was erased under the pressures of colonialism and nationalism. It wasn't until the LGBTQ+ liberation movements of 1970s America that the world found a new beacon for equality.

title: Gay asylum seeker Andry Hern√°ndez Romero remains in danger, advocates warn
content: LGBTQ+ and immigrant rights advocates are expressing a mix of relief and fury after learning that Andry Hern√°ndez Romero, a gay Venezuelan asylum seeker who vanished into one of the world‚Äôs most notorious prisons under the Trump administration, has been released from El Salvador and returned to Venezuela following more than four months of silence, secrecy, and mounting outrage. But his supporters warn that because he initially left Venezuela to escape persecution for his sexual orientation, he remains unsafe.

title: Queerty Crossword: July 20, 2025
‚ÄúTramps Like Us,‚Äù LNX‚Äôs bop & Megan Stalter‚Äôs new show: 10 things we‚Äôre obsessed with this week
content:
Round of applause! Another week is in the books, and we all deserve some appreciation for suffering through the heat and, just, *gestures broadly*.

Thankfully, the past seven days of news was more than enough to keep our gay lil’ minds occupied.

Speaking of occupied, we learned some fruity facts about the Turkish armed forces, revisited Supergirl, and took gay lessons from a bi TikToker.

How about we take this to the next level?

Subscribe to our newsletter for a refreshing cocktail (or mocktail) of LGBTQ+ entertainment and pop culture, served up with a side of eye-candy.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

Plus, Johnny Sibilly got candid, the girls thirsted over a twinkfluencer, and we celebrated International Nonbinary People’s Day.

Aside from that, the sticky days have been filled with hot reads, heartwarming shows, and Lil Nas X again.

Drumroll please, now presenting the 10 things we’re obsessed with this week…

1. Tramps Like Us by Joe Westmoreland

After more than two decades, Joe Westmoreland’s Tramps Like Us ($19 on Amazon) is back in print with an introduction by poet and writer Eileen Myles and an afterword from the author himself.

The ’80s autofictional classic has been called “an ode to a nearly lost generation,” following a young gay man who graduates from high school and goes out to find himself in New Orleans and San Francisco during the ’70s and ’80s. It’s a pivotal and personal novel, whose fans include Brandon Flynn.

2. Clue meets RuPaul’s Drag Race

Keep your hot takes on the latest season of RuPaul’s Drag Race All Stars to yourself! You’ll need all your wits about you for this unabashedly queer spin on the classic game of Clue, available for $44.98 online. The crown has gone missing, and you’ll have to search high and low in the werk room, untucked lounge, and on the main stage.

With characters like Madam Mustard and Crystal White, and 60+ minutes of gameplay, this fabulous and fierce mystery game will have you (and up to five of your best friends) serving Inspector Clouseau realness, hunny.

3. “HOT BOX” by Lil Nas X (again)

I don’t know why this pinkalicious and addictive Lil Nas X bop didn’t take off when he dropped it four months ago. That said, song of the summer contenders are looking dry, so I’m officially starting my campaign to bring this one back up the charts.

4. A gay TikTok parody that has no business being this funny

As a chronically online homosexual man, I laughed so hard at queer TikToker Chris Quazzo‘s Ice Spice remix of JoJo Siwa’s “Bette Davis Eyes” cover that I had to watch it four more times. (Yes, I know none of those words are in the Bible.)

5. Gap Logo Tote Bag

Have you ever seen a canvas tote manage to look this soft masc, and cute at the same time? (Don’t answer that.) When this Gap bag ‚Äî available in bainbridge blue, khaki tan, black, thyme green, starting at $29 online ‚Äî came across my feed this week, I knew no beach trip would ever be the same. With an overdyed style, sturdy strap, and inner and outer patch pockets, it’s giving ’90s flashbacks in the best way possible.

6. A meditation from Aja

These end-of-the-world words from Drag Race‘s Aja transposed over the intro to Chappell Roan’s “Super Graphic Ultra Modern Girl” got me through this week.

7. Too Much on Netflix

The premise of Lena Dunham’s new Netflix series ‚Äî a hot mess American girl (Megan Stalter) moves to London fresh off a breakup and falls in love with a musician (White Lotus hottie Will Sharpe) ‚Äî sounded like it was written for me alone. I’m pleased to report that the ten-part series, now streaming on Netflix, is filled with hilarious performances, an impeccable soundtrack, heart-wrenching scenes, and a surprising amount of queer chaos.

Messy gays and Love Actually lovers, the Girls writer and actress did this one for us.

8. Andy Sklar’s “Desert Trails” prints

It’s giving, “Wish I were in a pool right now.” These prints on The Pride Store from Andy Sklar’s Desert Trails series would add a tasteful but queer sensibility to any room. Which is why I’ve been desperately rearranging my gallery wall all week in hopes of squeezing one in!

My favorites are Friday Arrivals (12″x9″ for $49), F&N Pool Pop (12″x11.5″ for $119), and The Sundowners (14×11 or 12×9, starting at $49). I wasn’t familiar with the San Jacinto Mountains prior to the queer artist’s work, but now I must drink a martini there before I expire.

9. Gabby Windey getting to host a reality show

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Hulu (@hulu)

Gabby Windey is the best lesbian thing to happen to reality TV in years. Thankfully, the Traitors alum just got a solid gig as host of Hulu’s new on-the-sea dating reality show, and gay or straight, I will be tuning in just for her.

10. Tom of Finland Playing Cards

I’m of the personal belief that every residence ‚Äî especially every gay household ‚Äî should own a deck of cards. And while a standard set is perfectly fine, you really can’t beat the history (or heat) of the Tom of Finland Foundation and Kweer Card’s Tom of Finland Playing Cards ($19.99 on Amazon).

Each of the 54 cards features a different iconic gay illustration and a luxe matte varnish. Whether you’re playing solitaire or strip poker, they’re sure to liven up the evening. Just make sure all your men make it back into the box after the game’s over!

Another week of books, boys, and bops!

title: A closeted star, his beard, and one of the greatest American epics of all time
content:
Welcome back to our queer film retrospective,¬†‚ÄúA Gay Old Time.‚Äù¬†In this week‚Äôs column,¬†with a new Superman dominating the box office, let‚Äôs revisit the campiest movies of the franchise, 1984‚Äôs¬†Supergirl.

As we discuss in this column every week, there are many different elements that can make a movie queer. Yes, there are the obvious factors: the overt storylines that revolve around same-sex love and attraction, the coded characters whose traits and behaviors imply their sexuality, and the broad performances and aesthetics that directly appeal to our camp sensibilities.

But then there are also the elements that happen outside the film itself or behind the scenes that can also infuse a movie with a particular sense of queerness. From gay directors that are able to filter the stories through their own lived-in experiences and give them completely new and different themes, to queer actors (closeted or otherwise) who instill complicated layers to the characters they play, even if the narrative itself has nothing to do with queerness.

How about we take this to the next level?

Subscribe to our newsletter for a refreshing cocktail (or mocktail) of LGBTQ+ entertainment and pop culture, served up with a side of eye-candy.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

This week, we’ll be discussing a movie considered to be one of the greatest American films ever made, but one that‚Äôs not often talked about as a queer one. However, it can easily be seen with a sense of legacy and meaning today because of its two stars, both of whom had direct lifelong ties to our community.

The Set-Up

A Place In The Sun is a 1951 tragic melodrama directed by George Stevens, starring Montgomery Clift, Elizabeth Taylor, and Shelley Winters. It follows George Eastman (Clift), a poor, young class worker who moves to the big city to find a job with his rich industrial uncle. He then begins to lead a secret double life between dating Alice Tripp (Winters), one of his simple co-workers, and courting Angela Vickers (Taylor) a rich socialite, as his ambition and greed slowly begin to eat away at him and his relationships.

The film is based on the 1925 novel An American Tragedy by Theodore Dreiser, and it became a critical and commercial success upon its release, winning six Academy Awards (including Best Director and Screenplay, plus nominations for both Clift and Winters) and the first Golden Globe for Motion Picture Drama. It‚Äôs often considered one of the most biting portrayals of American ambition, greed, and capitalism, and cemented its actors as some of the most profitable and recognizable movie stars of the time.

And it would be no exaggeration to call A Place in the Sun a masterpiece. The film excels in every aspect of its production, from the immaculate composition of the scenes to the deliberate use of cinematography; the camera tends to remain still in long sequences, letting the action play in front making us feel less like passive viewers and more like overhearing private conversations, and it frames the close-ups of its stars like they are other-worldly beings. The swelling music elevates the emotions lying underneath each scene, and the script is a tight exploration of American values that nonetheless keeps you at the edge of your seat.

Montgomery Clift delivers perhaps the best performance of his career as George Eastman, a ruthless social climber that emanates charm and vulnerability and knows how to weaponize it. Shelley Winters embodies the trope of an insecure and modest young woman who desperately wants to be loved and will cling to affection until it leads to her demise. And Elizabeth Taylor, in one of the first adult roles in her career, is completely mesmerizing as a young socialite who is blindsided when the world she thought she knew falls apart.

Related

Closeted Hollywood legend Montgomery Clift starred in some of the gayest movies of the Hays Code era
Today marks what would be Monty’s 103rd birthday.

True Star Power

Most of the queerness that exists in or around this movie does so solely in retrospect. Montgomery Clift and Elizabeth Taylor would go on to become two hugely important figures in the queer history of classic Hollywood: the former as a troubled, closeted star with his own tragic ending, and the latter as a fierce advocate for the rights of the LGBTQ+ community during the AIDS crisis and beyond, mainly stemming from the close friendship the two held.

Although they are playing love interests in this movie (and one of the most swoon-worthy couples to ever grace the silver screen, at that), it‚Äôs hard not to read into it the bond that they were forming off screen at the time of filming, and that would lead to a lifelong friendship. The pair would reunite in two more movies after that, 1957‚Äôs Raintree Country and 1959‚Äôs Suddenly, Last Summer (a film with much more explicit queer themes) before Clift’s untimely death from a car accident in 1966.

Elizabeth Taylor was in fact the first person to publicly declare that Montgomery Clift was gay at the 2000 GLAAD Media Awards, as she was receiving an award for her tireless work for the queer community, although reports have varied since on whether Clift was bi or gay. We will never learn the exact truth, but it is clear that he moved through his life with a simultaneous openness and guard that is consistent with other closeted stars of the time.

Clift‚Äôs public relationships always felt more platonic than romantic, while at the same time he was able to embed his roles with a vulnerability and complexity that pointed to a troubled inner life. George Eastman is a perfect example of this. On paper George is a ruthless, remorseless scoundrel that goes to extreme measures to get what he wants, but Clift not only makes him human, but someone we find ourselves rooting for until it‚Äôs too late. He turns a villain into an underdog.

Shining Brightly, 75 Years Later

A Place in the Sun may exist in the queer canon retroactively. But given the history of Hollywood to erase and hide us, it‚Äôs undoubtedly not the only one. In the 1950s, the film was an exquisitely made examination of the lengths we go to get what we think we deserve. Almost 75 years later, it is also a vessel for two beloved stars and icons whose legacy with our community we are able to read into as they fall in love on screen.

A Place In The Sun¬†is currently streaming on Amazon Prime Video, The Criterion Channel & Hoopla, and is available for digital rental or purchase via AppleTV.

You can keep track of all LGBTQ+ films covered in our A Gay Old Time column via writer Jorge Molina‚Äôs handy Letterboxd List.

title: It‚Äôs National Football Day & these gridiron gays are ready to get tackled
content:
The NFL declared ‚Äúfootball is gay‚Äù in a 2021 video‚Äîadding in a tweet that the organization stands by the LGBTQ+ community‚Äîand as we hit another National Football Day on Saturday, July 19, social media is full of gay fans enjoying the sport (or, at least, its outfits).

Then again, homophobia still runs rampant on and off the football field. A head coach¬†was revealed to have used homophobic as misogynistic slurs¬†in 2021‚Äîhe resigned‚Äîand a kicker¬†called LGBTQ+ pride a mortal sin¬†just last year‚Äîhe‚Äôs still playing.

Luckily, there are openly gay players‚Äîand allies‚Äîat the college and professional level. Retired NFL athlete Ryan O‚ÄôCallaghan, who came out as gay in 2017, told¬†Reuters¬†in 2019 that there‚Äôs probably ‚Äúat least one‚Äù player on every NFL team ‚Äúwho is either gay or bisexual.‚Äù

How about we take this to the next level?

Subscribe to our newsletter for a refreshing cocktail (or mocktail) of LGBTQ+ entertainment and pop culture, served up with a side of eye-candy.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

Then, in 2021, then-Oakland Raiders lineman Carl Nassib¬†came out as gay, becoming the first active NFL player to do so.

Related

Kennedy McDowell is an out gay college football star who was never in the closet
When Kennedy McDowell walked on Colorado State’s campus last year, he was already an out gay man.

Brendon Ayanbadejo, a straight athlete, started advocating for same-sex marriage in 2009, when he was a Baltimore Ravens linebacker. And he celebrated Nassib‚Äôs coming out more than a decade later. ‚ÄúI think the good thing about the NFL is it‚Äôs really a young guys‚Äô sport, and the younger players are a lot more accepting and understanding of the fight for equality for LGBTQ+,‚Äù Ayanbadejo said at the time, per NFL.com.

Plus, a 2021 Morning Consult poll showed that about 1 in 3 LGBTQ+ adults said they were more likely to watch NFL games following Nassib‚Äôs coming out.

On Instagram, gay fans have shared photos of themselves attending football games, watching the action from home, playing flag football, or just posing in football garb. Here are their pics‚Ä¶

title: Tr*mp‚Äôs health issues multiply, Pete Buttigieg dominates the bros, Obama‚Äôs gay decree
content:
While¬†this steamy gay Belgian series and Tom Daley’s skimpy speedo¬†tried to keep our minds off of the Chaos-in-Chief, the red hat cultists, unqualified cabinet members and autocrats in the White House were busy doing all sorts of things you may have missed. Here‚Äôs just a few of the stories you really need to know about‚Ä¶

DRAG HIM: Democratic California Governor Gavin Newsom laid into the far-right, convicted felon president in the best and most brutal way possible. [Read more]

SASHAY AWAY: MAGA nutjob Marjorie Taylor Greene had a hissy fit over ‚Äúdrag queen story time‚Äù as she defended the convicted felon president’s Epstein friendship. [Read more]

Politics, but make it gay!

Stay woke with our briefing while staying informed on all things LGBTQ+ entertainment, life, and more!
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

NURSE! Amid his swollen ankle syndrome, the 79-year-old convicted felon president blamed Joe Biden for putting Jerome Powell as head of the Federal Reserve forgetting that he appointed him in 2017.

NOT SO FAST, CHEETO: The convicted felon president tried to cut $6.2M in HIV/AIDS funding and a federal court just stopped him. [Read more]

DEBASEMENT 101: Ultra pious House Speaker Mike Johnson found himself ensnared in the middle of convicted felon president’s dirty Jeffrey Epstein drama. [Read more]

GAY BESTIES: While making us extremely nostalgic for the days of having an eloquent Commander-In-Chief, President Barack Obama explained why all young men need gay friends and role models. [Read more]

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by The Jasmine Brand (@the.jasmine.brand)

AND JUSTICE FOR ALL: A federal judge ordered the release of a trans asylum seeker wrongfully detained in a men‚Äôs facility. [Read more]

WIN, LOSE OR DRAW: The bombshell report detailing the convicted felon president’s “bawdy” letter and doodle to Jeffrey Epstein makes you wonder if sending pervy drawings to your friends is actually pretty gay. [Read more]

EVERYBODY LOVES PETE: Former Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg continued to dominate the manosphere by making a hilarious cameo to present the Lib of the Year award on Barstool Sports’ Pardon My Take podcast. The podcast bros can’t get enough of President Mayor Pete. [Read more]

SPEAK UP! Eight bipartisan members of Congress launched a legislative pressure campaign to restore funding to the 988 national crisis support line‚Äôs special services for LGBTQ+ youth that the convicted felon president completely defunded. Seven were Democrats, including gay Reps. Sharice Davids (D-KS) and Chris Pappas (D-NH), with New York Rep. Mike Lawler being the lone Republican. [Read more]

title: Queerty Crossword: July 19, 2025
Trump cuts LGBTQ+ suicide line, QPOC break Emmy records & Rosie threatened with loss of citizenship
content:
Rep. Andrea Salinas is fighting to protect the LGBTQ+ suicide line from Trump‚Äôs cuts

Key number: 1.5 million, which is the number of calls the LGBTQ+ suicide line has taken since it was launched in 2022.

Why it matters: The LGBTQ+ youth crisis line has helped many LGBTQ+ people, and the Trump administration is shutting it down to save relatively little money. Democrats are right to try to save it, or at least make Trump face political repercussions for shutting it down.

LGBTQ+ people of color will break records and make history with this year‚Äôs Emmy nominations

Insights for the LGBTQ+ community

Subscribe to our briefing for insights into how politics impacts the LGBTQ+ community and more.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

Who is breaking records: Bowen Yang is now the most-nominated Asian male performer ever. Ayo Edebiri is the first Black woman ever nominated in several categories. RuPaul Charles is now the most-nominated reality TV host of all time.

Why it matters: Even in the face of an anti-LGBTQ+ backlash, queer people are getting recognized for their cultural contributions. Queer people of color, who have often been ignored in the media, are getting honored as well.

Rosie O‚ÄôDonnell slams Trump for his attempt to deport her: ‚ÄúOld soulless man with dementia‚Äù

Her reaction: “I am very proud to be opposed to every single thing he says and does and represents. I think he‚Äôs a racist and he‚Äôs misogynistic and he‚Äôs sexist.”

Why it matters: The president is trying to revoke the citizenship of an American because she spoke out against him, which is an authoritarian move that previous presidents haven’t even been willing to suggest publicly.

Democrats cheer as GOP governor vetoes two anti-LGBTQ+ bills

What she vetoed: An anti-trans bathroom bill, a book banning bill, and a ban on teachers giving students ‚Äúget to know you‚Äù questionnaires without parental permission.

Why it matters: Gov. Kelly Ayotte showed that even Republican governors can push back against the current anti-trans panic.

City paints over Pride crosswalk on orders from Trump & Ron DeSantis

Key quote: “Political banners have no place on public roads,” Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said.

Why it matters: Rainbow crosswalks and other street art have become a symbol for acceptance from municipal governments. The right is pushing back because they don’t want that acceptance in public spaces.

Here‚Äôs a picture

“Good Trouble Lives On” protests were held across the country yesterday, with marchers criticizing the administration and holding signs with messages like “No Kings” and anti-ICE slogans. There were also Pride flags visible at many of the protests.


And here are some interesting queer and trans reads.

Conservatives want to separate trans & reproductive rights. Trans men are uniting the movements.

LGBTQ Nation’s Summer Issue “What trans men teach us about masculinity” launched this week, and the cover story from journalist Zane McNeill examines how trans men’s fights for reproductive freedom and trans rights can’t be separated.

My dad struggled when I came out as a trans man. Then he danced with me at my wedding.

A heartwarming piece from essayist Ryan Cassata about dancing with his dad at his wedding.

Zach Wahls helped defeat a marriage ban in Iowa. Now he‚Äôs running against the ban‚Äôs sponsor.

Zach Wahls made headlines in 2011 when he testified in support of his two moms in the Iowa legislature to defeat a marriage ban. Now he’s running against the person who introduced that ban – Sen. Joni Ernst (R-IA) – for a seat in the Senate.

The Supreme Court‚Äôs latest ‚Äúcruel blow‚Äù could make it a lot harder to win trans rights cases

Iconic LGBTQ+ rights attorney Shannon Minter sat down with LGBTQ Nation contributor Greg Owen to discuss the implications of the recent Supreme Court decision in U.S. v. Skrmetti, which permitted states to ban trans health care for minors.

Subscribe to the¬†LGBTQ Nation newsletter¬†and be the first to know about the latest headlines shaping LGBTQ+ communities worldwide.

title: Russian bookstore raided & faces criminal prosecution for ‚ÄúLGBT propaganda‚Äù
content:
A bookstore in St. Petersburg, Russia is being accused for a second time by the government of spreading “LGBT propaganda,” the Russian website Bumaga reports, according to Novaya Gazeta.

The bookstore, Podpisnye Izdaniya (which means “subscription publications” in English), was raided in April, and dozens of LGBTQ+ and feminist books were seized as evidence. The prosecutor’s office said that many of the books had “signs of LGBT ideology.”

Related

Russia is building an electronic registry of LGBTQ+ citizens
Raids across the country are yielding the data to supply it.

Authorities gave the bookstore a list of titles that they were told to stop displaying or selling, including the book On Women by out writer Susan Sontag, which is a collection of essays and interviews about feminism, sexuality, and fascism.

Never Miss a Beat

Subscribe to our newsletter to stay ahead of the latest LGBTQ+ political news and insights.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

“Our books often appear on various insane lists,” said Mikhail Kotomin, the head of the publisher Ad Marginem. “It‚Äôs often weird choices such as One Way Street by Walter Benjamin or Discipline and Punish by Michel Foucault.”

Foucault was a gay French theorist from the mid-20th century who died early on in the AIDS crisis, who is best known for analyzing the relationship between power and knowledge. Benjamin was a German-Jewish essayist associated with the Frankfurt School who died in France while escaping the Third Reich.

In May, the store was convicted on charges of promoting LGBT propaganda and fined 800,000 rubles (about $10,000).

Yelena Orlova, the store’s manager, was also convicted on a charge of running an “undesirable organization” for selling a copy of the book On the Way to Magadan, a book about imprisonment by Belarusian anarchist author Ihar Alinevich. Orlova was fined 20,000 rubles ($256).

The bookstore was charged with a second count of promoting LGBT propaganda and was supposed to have another hearing last week, but Navoya Gazeta reports that the case was dropped after that hearing due to the statute of limitations of 90 days running out.

title: This philosopher & Holocaust survivor said fascism starts with the executive. Let‚Äôs listen.
content:
‚ÄúI told you once that I was searching for the nature of evil. I think I‚Äôve come close to defining it: a lack of empathy. It‚Äôs the one characteristic that connects all the [Nazi] defendants. A genuine incapacity to feel with their fellow man. Evil, I think, is the absence of empathy.‚Äù

Captain Gustav Mark Gilbert, a United States psychologist assigned to attend and closely observe the defendants at the Nuremberg Trials at the end of World War II, identified this common personality trait among all those who testified.

Related

It’s time to remember why we started the LGBTQ+ movement in the first place
Assimilation was never the goal.

Though I have studied the Holocaust and other genocides, I always had the gnawing and seemingly unanswerable question pulling at me, ‚ÄúHow could these episodes have taken place throughout the ages?‚Äù

Never Miss a Beat

Subscribe to our newsletter to stay ahead of the latest LGBTQ+ political news and insights.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

As we understand in psychology, unless there is a developmental delay, infants demonstrate the rudimentary beginnings of empathy whenever they recognize that another is upset and show signs of being upset themselves. Very early in their lives, infants develop the capacity to crawl in the diapers of others even though their own diapers do not need changing.

Though empathy is a human condition, the process of socialization often teaches us to inhibit our empathetic nature with messages like, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt cry,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre too sensitive,‚Äù ‚ÄúMind your own business,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not your concern.‚Äù We learn the stereotypes of the individuals and groups our society has ‚Äúminoritized‚Äù and ‚Äúothered,” and we learn who to scapegoat for our problems.

Through it all, that precious life-affirming flame of empathy can wither and flicker. For some, it dies entirely. As the blaze recedes, the bullies, the demagogues, the tyrants take over, filling the void where our humanity once prevailed. And then, we have lost something very precious.

The Nazi defendants at the Nuremberg Trials represent the termination of empathy on the individual micro level, resulting in the otherwise potentially preventable mass murders of Jews and other groups targeted by the Hitler regime. When the demise of empathy comes from powerful leaders, the consequences on the macro level become exponentially deeper, more toxic, and unimaginably catastrophic.

Several brilliant texts have investigated the unifying themes that connect the rise of dictatorial, autocratic regimes throughout history, including Ruth Ben-Ghiat‚Äôs¬†Strongmen: Mussolini to the Present, and Timothy Snyder‚Äôs¬†On Tyranny: Twenty Lessons from the Twentieth Century¬†and¬†On Freedom.

The acclaimed pioneer of discussions on totalitarianism, political responsibility, and the nature of evil is Hannah Arendt (1906-1975), a German Jewish historian and philosopher.

Arendt’s work focuses on the nature of political life. She explores the concepts of power, action, and¬†totalitarianism, defining the latter as a novel form of government characterized by both terror and false logic. She emphasized its reliance on ideology, isolation of individuals, and the concept of “superfluous people,” where individuals are reduced to their bodies and deemed expendable.

Arendt differentiated between ‚Äúpower‚Äù and ‚Äúviolence‚Äù by asserting that power arises from collective action and shared decision-making, while violence is a tool of control. Totalitarian regimes terminate individual freedoms while manipulating public opinion.   

She found that totalitarian regimes use the element of terror not merely as a means of eliminating the opposition, but also as a primary means of controlling the entire population. They do not rule through a sort of haphazard power, but rather, through a cruel logic justifying their actions.¬†

These regimes depend on powerful ideologies to isolate individuals from one another. Severing their ties with other people then creates feelings of loneliness and vulnerability. Totalitarianism feeds off the collapse of social connections, which makes individuals more receptive to exploitation and control.¬†

Arendt‚Äôs notion of ‚Äúsuperfluous people‚Äù informs us how totalitarian regimes diminish and cheapen human life to mere bodies, which one can reject and dispose of without any moral significance.  

She refers to totalitarianism as rather different from other forms of oppression by underscoring its distinctive means of control and domination. The Nazi movement, for example, was based on grievance, retribution, fear, scapegoating, and stereotyping, not¬†on a clear ideology.¬†¬†

Arendt saw the crisis as something that humanity could easily repeat. She believed her entire generation needed to answer the questions:

¬∑       What happened?

¬∑       Why did it happen?

¬∑       How did it happen?

Her answers to these questions resonate with those of us today who live in so-called ‚Äúdemocratic republics” whose institutions are under attack due to the unbalancing of power by hostile executive branches.¬†

We live in an era of uncertainty, where the current United States government no longer conforms to the rules in its cherished Constitution, in which the three branches – legislative, executive, and judicial – were created as equal partners in the balance of power.

Arendt wrote extensively on the process by which formerly democratic republics were destroyed from within, rather than by external invading forces.

Arendt’s Journey

Born in 1909 in Hanover, Germany, into a secular Jewish family, Arendt grew up in a highly educated home in which her parents endorsed Enlightenment principles of equality. Her great-grandparents fled the pogroms that targeted Jews throughout central and eastern Europe, and she studied the roots and causes of antisemitism.

Her family moved to Konigsberg when she was young. They resettled over safety concerns in Berlin during WWI. In 1924, following the war, Arendt entered the University of Marburg to study philosophy and ancient Greek.

Arendt barely escaped the terror of Nazi Germany and moved as a refugee to the United States, where she eventually became a naturalized citizen. There, she lived through the uncertainty and turmoil of the McCarthy and Watergate eras, but she was also encouraged by the youth movement‚Äôs resistance to the country‚Äôs incursion into Vietnam and Cambodia.

Even before entering university, she was well grounded in the ideas of the major philosophers, having read many of their works in her parents‚Äô well-stocked home library. She was particularly drawn to the ideas of Kant, Hegel, and Plato, who discussed how humans are thinking beings, and the fact that how one thinks has consequences for others.

At Marburg, she studied with philosopher and professor Martin Heidegger, one of the early thinkers in the emerging branch of existentialism. Heidegger’s work expressed the idea that there is nothing to ground us except what we make of our own being and that one can exist fearlessly on one‚Äôs own terms.

Arendt pursued the idea of a unified ‚Äúpassionate thinking‚Äù over the traditional philosophical distinction between reason and passion. She¬†wrote, ‚ÄúWe are so accustomed to reason over passion, spirit over life, that the idea of a passionate thinking in which thinking and aliveness become one, takes us somewhat aback.‚Äù

In 1924, Arendt and Heidegger became lovers. Arendt was 18, and Heidegger – a married man with young sons – was 35. Though Arendt eventually married two different men – a Jewish man named Gunter Stern and later, a non-Jewish Marxist,¬†Heinrich Bl√ºcher¬†– and though Heidegger seemingly embraced Nazism later in life, Arendt and Heidegger‚Äôs stimulating intellectual and complex relationship continued for decades and remained an essential feature of their lives and legacies.¬†

Arendt lived in Berlin in 1929 and became a journalist while working on her university dissertation on the ideas of St. Augustine‚Äôs theme of love, specifically neighborly love in which one holds a responsibility to others in the world. St. Augustine believed that when new people populate the globe, they can act to change the world: ‚ÄúMan was born, a beginning was made.‚Äù

But Arendt witnessed what she referred to as a ‚Äúculture of death‚Äù following WWI in which the world was in turmoil with extreme homelessness and financial insecurity, where people‚Äôs roots had been torn apart and where migrants moved between borders, especially Jews, Slavs, Pols, and Roma.

The world economic crash of 1929 increased Germany‚Äôs hyperinflation through which the Deutschemark lost most of its value. Within an environment where the people were extremely uncertain and fearful about the future in their nation, one that was already saturated with antisemitism, Hitler and his Nazi party saw the vision of the migrant Jews as their stepping stones to come to the very center of politics.

He blamed the Jews for the nation‚Äôs problems, inventing the conspiracy of the menacing and controlling Jews who are invading the country .

In the general elections that followed, Hitler‚Äôs propaganda advanced the false claim that the Nazis constituted a majority, even though they never did numerically. They presented the Illusion of popularity to give the appearance of strength.

Arendt identified that Hitler used his lies to convince the German people that he existed as their cherished leader who would lead them to better times. He made it so the distinction between fact and fiction no longer existed.

Hitler was skilled at understanding that the people were lonely and longed for a sense of meaning and belonging. His movement recruited followers from the extensive pool of indifferent and disconnected people whom the other political parties had considered apathetic or too ignorant to become involved.

Ultimately, Nazi members comprised those who had not before engaged deeply in the political process. Leaders offered them the possibility of being part of something big, which gave them a sense of meaning and purpose.¬†

Other conservative politicians may have tried to dominate him, but Hitler was wise enough to play them against each other. After realizing they could not control him and recognizing the need for his support, they assisted in his promotion to Chancellor of Germany in 1933.

Though Arendt was not particularly involved in electoral politics, February 27, 1933, became a turning point with the destructive burning of the Reichstag building and the illegal arrests and detentions the following night. Though evidentiary reports point to the Nazis themselves being responsible for the blaze, they blamed the communists and declared martial law.¬†

Arendt‚Äôs first husband, Gunter Stern, was forced to flee. She somehow felt responsible. Some people were shipped to concentration camps. She felt that at times like this, one must spring into action and not become a bystander.

She converted her apartment into a safe space for communists who were preparing to leave Germany as the Nazis were readying themselves to take over all the levers of government. Hitler promoted himself as a calm, steadfast leader [a ‚Äústable genius?”].

Arendt worked for an old friend, Kurt Blumenfeld, who served as secretary of the¬†Zionist Federation of Germany¬†from 1909 to 1911 and later served as president of the organization from 1924 to 1933, when he fled the rising tide of antisemitism in Nazi Germany for Palestine.

Blumenfeld wanted to document antisemitic statements and actions, and he wanted to publicize his work around the world to bring it to the attention of world leaders. He asked Arendt to spearhead this project because members of the Zionist Federation of Germany could not, as they would be exposed and arrested. She said yes.

A librarian reported Arendt to the Gestapo for reading too many newspapers. She was arrested while walking out of the library and imprisoned at Alexanderplatz, Gestapo headquarters.

She remained in prison as the Gestapo searched her apartment, but they could only find her Greek notebooks. She lied about her involvement with the Zionist organization, and they released her. They confiscated her passport so she could not leave the country. She fled to Czechoslovakia and eventually reached Paris in 1933.

There was a massive anti-immigrant backlash in France. There,, she worked for an organization that helped send youth to Palestine – Jungen Aliah. She spent 3 months in Israel, where she advocated for a binational federation where Jews and Arabs could live and work together and where they all could make Palestine their homeland.

She met Heinrich Bl√ºcher, who was not Jewish, and separated from Stern, her husband. Bl√ºcher had no formal education. He was a cabaret performer and a Marxist street fighter during the Russian Revolution.

In March 1938, Germany invaded Austria. On September 1, 1939, Germany invaded Poland and started WWII. Arendt was sent to a transit camp in southern France, where she eventually escaped, while most others were shipped to Auschwitz.

Heinrich and Arendt reunited. They went to Marseilles to get a permit to leave France, and they fled on a boat to New York City.¬†

She tracked the atrocities occurring in Germany and its conquered territories and began her book,¬†Origins of Totalitarianism, in 1943. It was published in 1951. Some of the recurring themes she discovered in the totalitarianism of the Nazis included:

1.     Propaganda provides the foundation for building totalitarian power.

2.     The Nazis translated the propaganda lies of the movement into a functioning reality.

3.     Totalitarianism replaces all first-rate talent with crackpots and fools whose lack of intelligence and creativity is the best guarantee of their loyalty.

4.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†The Nazis acted as if the world were dominated by the Jews and needed a counter-conspiracy to defend itself.

Arendt was convinced that while it may not recur identically as in Germany, totalitarianism is very likely to return. Therefore, the people must continually remain vigilant, prepared, and informed. She was reminded of her work on St. Augustine in the phrase: ‚ÄúMan is born, a beginning is made,‚Äù and that people have the ability to make the world anew.¬†

At the end of the war in Europe, Hannah worked for a Jewish reconstruction organization. She traveled back to Germany to reclaim Jewish property. There, she visited Heidegger, and they talked for many hours in constructive and healing dialogue.  

Back in the United States during the McCarthy terror campaigns, she taught courses in political science at the University of California Berkeley, and officials in the U.S. government threatened to¬†denaturalize¬†her.

McCarthy‚Äôs totalitarian elements emerged even in the absence of an organized movement and without a clear ideological foundation. Arendt rightly claimed that McCarthyism held more fear for Jewish refugees than native-born Americans could imagine.

For Arendt and most of her Jewish refugee friends, the original trust they had had in the protection of their adoptive country for their right of free thought disappeared during those years and never fully returned.

She traveled to Israel in April 1961 as a reporter to attend the Adolf Eichmann trial beginning in April 1961. Eichmann was responsible for many logisitcs of the concentration camps, one of which she was once held in. He was charged with ‚Äúcrimes against humanity.‚Äù

His defense was that he obeyed legal orders, and he could not think from the standpoint of someone else, from the standpoint of his victims. In other words, he lacked empathy.

This Arendt termed ‚Äúthe banality of evil,‚Äù whereby, in Eichmann‚Äôs case, herding Jews and others into the gas chambers and ovens became as regular and normalized as herding cattle for slaughter. For ordinary people, the routine killing of masses of people became normalized.

In 1963, she published her¬†Eichmann in Jerusalem: A Report on the Banality of Evil, and¬†wrote: ‚ÄúThe trouble with Eichmann was precisely that so many were like him, and that the many were neither perverted nor sadistic, that they were, and still are, terribly and terrifyingly normal. From the viewpoint of our legal institutions and of our moral standards of judgment, this normality was much more terrifying than all the atrocities put together.‚Äù

From her work on St. Augustine, she was encouraged by the youth whom she understood as maintaining the possibility of being the agents of social change.

She was clear when she wrote that: ‚ÄúI have no desire to watch another republic going to the dogs.‚Äù

The Watergate conspiracy under Richard Nixon had revealed one of the deepest constitutional crises the United States had ever known. Arendt believed that the entire fabric of government was actually at stake.

She wrote that the nation‚Äôs founders never believed tyranny could arise from the executive office.

‚ÄúHowever, we know today that the greatest danger of tyranny is of course from the executive. If fascism is going to come to America, it is from the executive branch.‚Äù

In her final public address, her ‚ÄúHome to Roost‚Äù speech, presented at the Bicentennial Forum in Boston, Massachusetts in 1975, she said, ‚ÄúOne of the discoveries of totalitarian governments with the method of digging giant holes in which to bury unwelcomed facts and events, for the past was condemned to be forgotten as though it never had been. But I rather believe with Faulkner who wrote that ‚Äòthe past is never dead. It is not even past.‚Äô And this for the simple reason that the world in which we live in at any moment is the world of the past.‚Äù

Hannah Arendt died in New York City on December 4, 1975.

Find more information from the¬†PBS¬†documentary: Hannah Arendt: Facing Tyranny

title: Huge victory as court says sports group can‚Äôt force female runner to take hormones
content:
Here are this week‚Äôs most popular positive stories, with some fun social media posts tossed in too. Like seeing uplifting content like this?¬†Sign up for our Good News email.

Even when the summer heat is on and the news is making us sweat, it’s important to remember that the LGBTQ+ community is still going loud and growing proud ‚Äî in big, beautiful ways. This week’s roundup has numerous instances of queer communities pulling together, families supporting each other, and some huge victories worldwide.

But before we jump in, did you hear how California is filling the gap after the president recently ended the helpline for LGBTQ+ youth? Did you hear about the newly unveiled Boston park honoring the trailblazing trans woman who inspired the Trans Day of Remembrance? And did you know that LGBTQ+ people of color broke records and made history with this year‚Äôs Emmy nominations?

She’s got Betty Davis eye! (singular)

Never Miss a Beat

Subscribe to our newsletter to stay ahead of the latest LGBTQ+ political news and insights.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

A post shared by Myles (@camp.o.rama)

Queer runner Caster Semenya wins legal victory against World Athletics‚Äô sports policy

The sports body tried to force her to reduce her testosterone levels. A higher court of human rights said, “No way.”

Daughter of Norwegian princess becomes country‚Äôs first royal to come out

Maud Angelica Behn earned the title of “Bravest Woman in Norway” in 2020, and she continues to demonstrate that bravery.

Community rallies against church’s anti-gay sermons

The protestors held signs that said, “Trans rights are human rights,” “Stop the hate,” and “True Christians preach love.”

Sylvester wants to funk with you!

Democrats cheer as GOP governor vetoes two anti-LGBTQ+ bills

Gov. Kelly Ayotte (R) called one of the laws “overly broad and impractical.”

Celebrate 10 years of marriage equality with 20 celebrity couples who wed during the last decade

Let wedding bells ring with these LGBTQ+ stars who’ve tied the knot.

My dad struggled when I came out as a trans man. Then he danced with me at my wedding.

There was no awkwardness. No performance of masculinity from either of us. Just love, plain and simple.

This modern mash-up of “The Birds” stars Outkast and Sesame Street

Ukraine court recognizes same-sex couple as a family in historic LGBTQ+ victory

White House reverses plans to cut global HIV/AIDS program PEPFAR

PEPFAR has saved millions of lives and will continue to do so.

Trans wrestling group provides a hot antidote to toxic masculinity

title: Local theater scene heats up for the season
content:
With all the fun and half the hassle, staycation has a lot going for it, and the performing arts can be a big part of the experience. Here‚Äôs some of what‚Äôs out there this summer.  

At Wolf Trap, the summer program is bursting with song, dance, and laughs. And if you‚Äôre quick, you can catch the sardonic wit of gay humorist David Sedaris in his one-night only show ‚ÄúAn Evening with David Sedaris‚Äù on July 19.  

Pink Martini is bringing its 30th anniversary tour to Wolf Trap on July 29. The self-described ‚Äútiny orchestra‚Äù known for its cosmopolitan musical stylings, features vocalists China Forbes and Storm Large along with special guest out radio journalist Ari Shapiro.

Other shows slated for the Vienna, Va., farm park include Broadway stars Sutton Foster and Kelli O‚ÄôHara accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra for an evening of showstoppers by Rodgers and Hammerstein, Sondheim, Cole Porter, Jason Robert Brown, and Joni Mitchell. (8/1) Wolftrap.org¬†

Perfectly timed for summer, Studio Theatre presents ‚ÄúWipeout‚Äù (through July 27). Playwright Aurora Real de Asua‚Äôs beach-set story looks to be a promising 110 minutes of humor and poignant moments. 

In ‚ÄúWipeout,‚Äù Claudia, played by terrific D.C. favorite Naomi Jacobson, treats herself and her two closest girlfriends to an early birthday present of surf lessons. 

Coached by ‚Äúsurf bro‚Äù instructor Blaze (played by handsome actor Alec Ludacka), Claudia is determined to slide into her golden years ‚Äúcatching some waves, and settling some scores.‚Äù 

Olney Theatre presents a fantastic, queer friendly summer program centered mainly around its open-air Root Family Stage (7/31-8/24). 

Highlights include hilarious out actor/singer Tituss Burgess in concert on Aug. 7, as well as the U.S. Premiere Concert presentation of ‚ÄúTo Wong Foo: The Musical‚Äù (8/21) and ‚ÄúJust Arts: From Stonewall to RuPaul Drag Extravaganza‚Äù (8/24) featuring big name drag performers Lala Ri and Latrice Royale. 

For those looking to beat the heat indoors, Olney has Synetic Theater performing its wordless version of ‚ÄúA Midsummer Night‚Äôs Dream‚Äù through Aug. 10. 

Replete with fairies, a fantastical forest, star-crossed lovers, and an actor transformed into a donkey, Synetic‚Äôs take on the Bard‚Äôs enchanting, Athens-set rom com is directed by Paata Tsikurishvili. Olneytheatre.org¬†

If kids (4 years and up) figure into your staycation plans, a trip to Bethesda‚Äôs Imagination Stage may be just the ticket. ‚ÄúDory Fantasmagory‚Äù (through Aug. 3) based on the children‚Äôs book by Abby Hanlon and adapted to the stage by John Glore, explores family dynamics while remaining both imaginative and fun. 

‚ÄúIt’s tough being the youngest. Dory’s siblings won’t play with her and there are monsters to battle all over the house, like the hair-raising Mrs. Gobble Gracker. With the help of her fairy godfather, Mr. Nuggy, her monster-friend, Mary, and her mighty imagination, Dory sets out to win what she wants most: her family’s attention.‚Äù 

Young theatergoers are encouraged to come in wacky outfits in the spirit of Dory‚Äôs playful style, and pajama Saturdays are also encouraged. Imaginationstage.org¬†

Young audiences may also enjoy ‚ÄúThe Lightning Thief‚Äù (through Aug. 17) presented by Adventure Theatre in Glen Echo Park. With music and lyrics by Rob Rokicki, this dynamic musical adaptation of Rick Riordan‚Äôs bestselling book opened on Broadway in 2019. 

Here‚Äôs the gist of the story. ‚ÄúWhen teenager Percy Jackson discovers he‚Äôs a demigod, he and his friends embark on an epic journey to find Zeus‚Äô missing lightning bolt and prevent a war among the gods.‚Äù Kurt Boehm directs. Adventuretheatre-mtc.org

At Signature Theatre, there‚Äôs some laid-back cabaret with ‚ÄúSailing: Yacht Rock‚Äù (July 22-Aug. 10) featuring terrific talents Deimoni Brewington and Tracy Lynn Olivera. 

Relax and possibly reminisce with chill tunes like ‚ÄúBrandy (You‚Äôre a Fine Girl),‚Äù ‚ÄúEscape (The Pina Colada Song)‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhat a Fool Believes.‚Äù It‚Äôs a chance to enjoy and revisit the sounds of Christopher Cross, TOTO, and the Doobie Brothers. Sigtheatre.org¬†

Washington National Opera (WNO) presents Opera in the Outfield (Aug. 23). The WNO invites theater and baseball fans to the Nationals Park for a free broadcast of Gershwin‚Äôs gorgeous classic ‚ÄúPorgy and Bess.‚Äù The screening starts at 6:30 p.m. 

At the Kennedy Center, summer staycation wraps up with ‚ÄúParade‚Äù (Aug. 19-Sept. 7), a powerful and celebrated 2023 Broadway revival musical. It‚Äôs based on the true story of Leo Frank, a Jewish factory superintendent in Atlanta wrongly accused and convicted of the murder of 13-year-old Mary Phagan in 1913. Co-conceived by the legendary Harold Prince, the production is a collaboration of some Broadway heavyweights including out director Michael Arden, Alfred Uhry (book), Jason Robert Brown (music & lyrics). Kennedy-center.org

The post Local theater scene heats up for the season appeared first on Washington Blade: LGBTQ News, Politics, LGBTQ Rights, Gay News.

title: At least 4 out LGBTQ players will play in the WNBA All-Star Game. Caitlin Clark drafted zero.
content:
With the WNBA All-Star game set for this Saturday, it’s a great time to root for the gay, lesbian and bi athletes to cheer extra for because, well, they deserve it. Please note that as always, these are only “publicly out” players ‚Äîmeaning each one has publicly acknowledged in the media, social media or in some way that they are LGBTQ, possibly in a relationship with another woman.

The WNBA All-Star game takes place this weekend in Indianapolis, with all events broadcast on ESPN. Team Clark and Team Collier will go head-to-head on Saturday night, with a skills challenge and three-point contest on Friday night. Though Clark, given an injury, is reportedly not going to participate. It wasn’t clear who would replace her.

The Indiana star was also supposed to headline the three-point contest on Friday, taking on last year’s champion Allisha Gray and the event record-holder, Sabrina Ionescu. Gray is also competing in in the Skills Challenge, alongside Natasha Cloud, Skylar Diggins, Erica Wheeler and Courtney Williams.

Without further adieu, your 2025 Gay All-Stars!

Get off the sidelines and into the game

Our weekly playbook is packed with everything from locker room chatter to pressing LGBTQ sports issues.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

Related

Caitlin Clark traded the coach who dissed her team ahead of the WNBA All-Star Game
Caitlin Clark will captain one of the two WNBA All-Star teams. But coach Cheryl Reeve will now coach her Lynx player, Napheesa Collier.

Team Clark

Headed by Indiana superstar Caitlin Clark, here are the publicly out LGBTQ WNBA All-Star Game players competing on Team Clark.

Bzzzzzzt.

While her roster may include LGBTQ players who haven’t come out publicly, Clark didn’t select any publicly out gay or bi players for her All-Star team — players who have acknowledged they are LGBTQ in the media or clearly on social media.

You know who did?

Related

The WNBA is loaded with out LGBTQ star players
The WNBA has numerous out LGBTQ players. Here is one per team to root for.

Team Collier

Napheesa Collier selected a few out LGBTQ players to play for her team in the game.

Paige Bueckers, Dallas Wings

No one is having a rookie season like Paige Bueckers. Sure, others have been chosen as an All-Star starter in their rookie season, but none of them have also broken the internet with the hard launch of their relationship with former UConn teammate Azzi Fudd. Bueckers won a national championship with Fudd at UConn just months ago, only to get drafted No. 1 overall by the Dallas Wings mere days later. In her rookie season, the guard was named June’s Rookie of the Month and currently leads all rookies in scoring, assists and (is tied first for) steals.

Breanna Stewart, New York Liberty

Getting herself some gay bonus points, New York Liberty forward Breanna Stewart has two children with former teammate Marta Xargay. Stewart most recently co-founded the offseason basketball league Unrivaled, and is making her seventh All-Star appearance.

Alyssa Thomas, Phoenix Mercury

Recently reunited in Phoenix with her fianc√©, Dewanna Bonner, Alyssa Thomas has been on a tear in the final games leading up to the All-Star break. Thomas is making her sixth All-Star appearance, first as a member of the Mercury.

Courtney Williams, Minnesota Lynx

Co-founder of the league’s hottest Twitch stream, StudBudz, Courtney Williams is making her second All-Star appearance in nine seasons. The Minnesota Lynx guard has been playing some of her best basketball ever, and coming off an electric first season in Unrivaled.

Reserves

As reserves, some players were not available top be drafted, but they will sub into the All-Star Game if there’s an injury. Interestingly, Clark herself may need to be replaced after a recent injury.

Kayla McBride, Minnesota Lynx

Recently tapped to fill in as a reserve for an injured Rhyne Howard, “McBuckets” is making her fifth All-Star appearance in her twelfth season. Fans of Unrivaled star (and anyone, really) will love the essay she penned for The Player’s Tribune in 2020, talking on her journey, and at times struggle, with her mental health.

title: The WNBA is loaded with out LGBTQ star players
content:
The 13-team WNBA has many out LGBTQ players and we are giving you one per team to root for. This list is not all-inclusive, but it shows the variety of talent in the league. We have updated the list to include Dallas Wings star Paige Bueckers.

Britney Griner, Atlanta Dream

If you know one name going into this season, make it “BG.” In 2022, Griner was detained in Russia for 10 months and the entire 2022 WNBA season was filled with calls and messages to “BRING BG HOME. Since her return, she has continued to be a celebrated figure in the league and starts her first season in Atlanta after 11 with Phoenix. And, now she’s a pops!

Courtney Vandersloot, Chicago Sky

Courtney Vandersloot is a longtime veteran of the WNBA. She is married to former Chicago Sky teammate ‚Äî and EuroLeague legend ‚Äî Allie Quigley. After some time on the New York Liberty, Vandersloot is back to her Chicago roots, leading a Sky team that includes rookie standouts Angel Reese, Kamilla Cardoso and 11th overall draft pick Hailey Van Lith.

Saniya Rivers, Connecticut Sun

Saniya Rivers is repping the Connecticut Sun’s LGBTQ+ status like no one else. As the 8th overall draft in the year’s class, Rivers had an electric college season at South Carolina and more recently, NC State. If you have not yet caught Rivers ‚Äî and now Sun teammate ‚Äî Marina Mabrey’s TikTok livestreams, please do yourself a favor and tune in.

DiJonai Carrington and NaLyssa Smith, Dallas Wings

This pair started as teammates at Baylor University under coach Kim Mulkey, and now find themselves teammates in Dallas. The Wings’ new signees DiJonai Carrington and NaLyssa Smith have taken our hearts as this year’s power couple to watch. We’re excited for these Texas lovebirds to be back on the same team, and bonus points that they get to welcome the team’s No. 1 overall draft pick, Paige Bueckers.

Paige Bueckers, Dallas Wings

Bueckers is a late addition to our list given her relationship with former UConn teammate Azzi Fudd.

Kate Martin, Golden State Valkyries

With a fan group that calls themselves “The Kate Martinis,” the WNBA’s latest expansion team got themselves a good one in former Las Vegas Aces guard Kate Martin. Martin had quite the 2024; she and her Iowa teammate Caitlin Clark led the Iowa Hawkeyes to the NCAA championship game and days later, while attending the draft to support Clark, Martin herself was drafted 18th overall by the Las Vegas Aces. After a successful rookie season in Las Vegas, and having spent time in Miami as part of the inaugural Unrivaled roster, Martin has a high ceiling on a Golden State team in its first season.

Dewanna Bonner, Indiana

Another mainstay of the WNBA, Dewanna Bonner finds herself on her third WNBA team in her storied career, this time separated from her fiancee, Alyssa Thomas. Bonner is a playoff star. Last season with Connecticut, she moved to first all-time in playoff games played, second all-time in playoff scoring, third all-time in playoff rebounding and steals and fifth all-time in playoff three-point field goals made.

Chelsea Gray, Las Vegas Aces

Also known as “The Point Gawd,” Chelsea Gray is always fun to watch. She and her wife now have one child, and Gray often gushes about her family. After time spent getting healthy in the offseason and a stellar Unrivaled championship win, Gray feels poised for a major 2025 season, with her family cheering her along the way.

Emma Cannon, Los Angeles Sparks

Since the retirement of the league’s first openly nonbinary legend, Layshia Clarendon, the Sparks had to be sure their roster reflected at least one member of the LGBTQ community. Enter WNBA veteran Emma Cannon. She’s been in the league for six seasons and in 2021 became the fifth woman in WNBA history to play for three different teams during the same season. She’s brought fire to the Sparks in their preseason games, and I’m hoping she can earn a spot on the final roster.

Courtney Williams, Minnesota Lynx

Whether she’s on or off the court, you know it’s a good time if Courtney Williams is in the room. Williams is always a joy to watch hoop, and the star recently launched a podcast with her equally undeniable father. After a dominate Unrivaled season with Lynx teammate Napheesa Collier, Williams shows no signs of slowing down this 2025 WNBA season. Oh, and did I mention this?

Breanna Stewart, New York Liberty

Unrivaled’s co-founder, four-time NCAA champion, three-time WNBA champion…and mother of two! Stewart recently led her Liberty to the franchise’s first title in 2024, and fans of the Liberty are grateful to be in Stew York City. Breanna Stewart is one-of-a-kind and a winner at every level.

Alyssa Thomas, Phoenix Mercury

Also known as “The Engine,” Alyssa Thomas has arrived in Phoenix, ready to fuel a hungry fan base. Thomas is engaged to former Connecticut Sun teammate DeWanna Bonner, who is now with Indiana. Thomas is a walking double-double and you know every Indiana-Phoenix matchup is sure to be heated.

Erica Wheeler, Seattle Storm

A new add to the Seattle Storm, Erica Wheeler is only the second undrafted player in WNBA history to reach 1,000 assists. The other player to accomplish this? Las Vegas Aces head coach and fellow gay icon Becky Hammon. This is all about Wheeler, though, and the star has it all. She’s both an elite offensive and defensive player and you can’t not root for a player who proposes to their girlfriend like this.

Stef Dolson, Washington Mystics

Big Mama Stef! Dolson is a fellow UConn Huskie, having won back-to-back titles with the team before being drafted 6th overall by the Washington Mystics in 2014. Dolson has played with the Chicago Sky and New York Liberty, but alas, she and her pup, Theo, are back in Washington, D.C. as Dolson enters her 11th WNBA season.

Jockular is a podcast by big-time women‚Äôs sports fans, for big-time women‚Äôs sports fans. E.R. Fightmaster, Katie Kershaw and Tien Tran. It‚Äôs produced by Harry Nelson and Charlie Smith. They‚Äôll be contributing women‚Äôs sports content for Outsports. You can find them on Spotify, Instagram, YouTube and Patreon.

June 18: This post was updated to include an out player from the Connecticut Sun.

Subscribe to the Outsports newsletter to keep up with your favorite out athletes, inspiring LGBTQ sports stories, and more.

title: Pride Pioneer: Olympic figure skater comes out as gay by kissing his boyfriend
content:
This post ran in 2016 and is being republished as part of our Pride Pioneers series.

Javier Raya, 25, an Olympic figure skater from Spain, has come out publicly as gay in the new-fashioned way: On Instagram, with a photo of him kissing his boyfriend.


Raya is on the left, Andrew Nicholson on the right. The caption read:

Many of you knows, others can imagine by the pictures and others will be surprised, but I have to say that right now I feel like the luckiest person in the world!
Thank you @nicholsondrew

The photo was posted three weeks ago, but did not get any attention outside of the Spanish media. Raya finished 25th in the 2014 men’s figure skating competition at the 2014 Winter Olympics.

Raya is the second major Spanish Olympic athlete to come out as gay in the past few weeks. He is joined by water polo Victor Gutierrez. If you understand Spanish, there is a video of Raya discussing Gutierrez and coming out.

Thanks to reader Jeff for the tip.

Here is another photo of Raya (right) and Nicholson, from the latter’s Instagram feed.

The post Pride Pioneer: Olympic figure skater comes out as gay by kissing his boyfriend appeared first on Outsports.

title: This WNBA scoring love triangle is perfectly WNBA
content:
DeWanna Bonner is now No. 5 on the all-time WNBA scoring list. She made the jump up one spot earlier this week when she scored 20 points over Indiana, lifting her Connecticut Sun team to the in Caitlin Clark’s debut WNBA game.

It wasn’t lost on a lot of people whom she passed in her meteoric rise up that list, and who noticed.

Before this week, the fifth-ranked career scoring leader in the WNBA had been her former Phoenix Mercury teammate, Candice Dupree. Bonner and Dupree had been married for several years. Bonner even had children while the two were together.

The two split up at some point.

Get off the sidelines and into the game

Our weekly playbook is packed with everything from locker room chatter to pressing LGBTQ sports issues.
Subscribe to our Newsletter today

Now, Bonner is engaged to marry her Sun teammate, Alyssa Thomas.

Likely to celebrate her fiancee, and not looking to throw shade, Thomas was effusive about Bonner’s accomplishment.

“I think she’s underrated,” Thomas said after Bonner’s big night. “Top 5 all-time, I mean c’mon. That’s unheard of. At her age, she’ incredible. We go off of her and she makes it look easy out there.”

Lindsay Gibbs was all over the dynamic.

dewanna bonner passed her ex-wife on the wnba's all-time leading scorer's list and then her fiance, her MVP-candidate teammate, got to talk about it on ESPN, there is nothing like women's sports

— Lindsay Gibbs (@linzsports) May 15, 2024

Related

As WNBA tips off, 20% of players currently on rosters are LGBTQ and publicly out
1 in 5 WNBA players are publicly out as LGBTQ, possibly the highest of any pro league in the world, to kick off the 2022 season.

Bonner is 36. She was the fifth overall pick in the 2009 WNBA Draft out of Auburn. She’s been with the Connecticut Sun since 2020. She’s a five-time WNBA All-Star, including two of the last three seasons with the Sun.

Bonner and Auburn celebrated the accomplishment.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Auburn Women's Basketball (@auburnwbb)

Bonner is now only a couple hundred points behind No. 4 Tina Charles, and almost 500 points behind No. 3, Tamika Catchings. She is in the upper echelon of great WNBA scorers, no doubt.

Though there’s virtually no way she’ll reach the top of the list, Diana Taurasi, who is over 3,000 points ahead of Bonner. She would have to average 20 points per game over the next four seasons, even as Taurasi continues to add to her total, to have a shot.

Regardless, the “love triangle” involving these two great WNBA scorers, as well as a fiancee, is pure WNBA.

The post This WNBA scoring love triangle is perfectly WNBA appeared first on Outsports.
